{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3156579,"name":"Axel G.","username":"axel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-03T16:39:26.023Z","cooked":"

We have a really bizarre issue that’s followed across two different motor-encoder sets.

We currently have two Neo-SparkMAX pairs that handle the movement for our robotic arm. We started out using two Falcon-500s for this, but quickly found that no they outright refused to turn more than one way. They will turn at a negative rpm, bringing the arm down, but refuse to turn at a positive rpm to bring it back up. We’ve tried changing our code about 50 times, adding logs to debug whether the methods are even called (they are), and then switch out the motors, and the issues persisted.

Any ideas why this would happen? Our arm is easy to operate (light and with a good gear ratio), and the motors have no problem when they do kick in going down (which should be harder because its working against two Vulcan springs).

I’ll second Mark’s guess here on the limit switches.

I’d recommend calling this method on the SparkMax during your robotInit method:

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/cansparkmaxlowlevel#restoreFactoryDefaults(boolean)

That will disable any limit switch settings and any other stored configs.

Then, after you set any configs that you want, call this method to make it persist to the SparkMax

https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/cansparkmax#burnFlash()

Looking at your arm code, it looks like you’re only sending 20% power, which might not be enough to make the arm move against gravity. What do the lights do on the Spark Max when you command it? If it still shows neutral this isn’t the problem, but if it shows a green/red blink, it would indicate it’s getting a commanded value, and it isn’t strong enough. It would also tell you if a limit switch is getting triggered unintentionally.

Alternately, have you verified that the your OI code has appropriate encoder values? If the encoder was returning values > -10, then it would only go down and not up.
